http://www.argusleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050701/NEWS/507010302/1001
 
 Judge puts abortion law on hold
 Published: 07/1/05
 federal judge Thursday blocked a South Dakota abortion law from taking effect today, tentatively ruling that the measure is an unconstitutional violation of free speech.
 
 The legislation would have required doctors to inform women that abortion ends the lives of "human beings" and poses various medical and psychological risks. Failure to give the informed-consent warning could have resulted in 30 days in jail and a $200 fine.
 
 U.S. District Judge Karen Schreier of Rapid City ruled that Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota, which sued the state, has shown it has a fair chance of winning on its claim that the proposed law infringes on the First Amendment rights of doctors.
 
 A hearing is set for October on Planned Parenthood's request for a permanent order barring the state from enacting the law.
 
 The measure, passed by the 2005 Legislature, would make a doctor inform a woman that she has a legal relationship with her "unborn child," and the relationship will be terminated by an abortion that will end the life of that "human being."
 
 "The South Dakota statute requires abortion doctors to enunciate the state's viewpoint on an unsettled medical, philosophical, theological and scientific issue - that is, whether a fetus is a human being," the judge wrote in an order granting Planned Parenthood a preliminary injunction. . . .

post_info.post_title: I Guess This Judge Won't Have a Shot at O'Connor's Seat

The legislation would have required doctors to inform women that abortion . . . . poses various medical and psychological risks. 

 
 Why would they want doctors to not inform patients of possible side-effects?

Why would they want doctors to not inform patients of possible side-effects?

 
 Wow, that question had almost nothing to do with the post. Did you cut and paste that in from another discussion by mistake?

Okey dokey, so in reference to:
 
The measure, passed by the 2005 Legislature, would make a doctor inform a woman that she has a legal relationship with her "unborn child," and the relationship will be terminated by an abortion that will end the life of that "human being."
What the devil does the preceding have to do with medical or emotional issues? The statement that a woman " has a legal relationship with her 'unborn child,' and the relationship will be terminated by an abortion that will end the life of that 'human being,'" imposes a mythical relationship upon the woman that does not exist. Why, all of a sudden, does a woman have "a legal relationship with her 'unborn child'"? Did she sign a contract with the entity that resides in her womb?
 
 To be quite frank, that is the goofiest off-the-wall statement I have ever seen.

The goofiest statement I've ever seen is the one that claims ending a life is not a medical issue.
 
 Agreed that this judge has no chance at the Supreme Court. Or, for that matter, an appointment to an appeals court.
